GRANT OF LANDS OF SRI LANKA MAHAWELI AUTHORITY
asked the Minister of Agriculture, Livestock, Land and Irrigation:
(i) the methodology adopted in granting the lands belonging to Sri Lanka Mahaweli Authority for large-scale projects;
(ii) the extent of land provided to companies named Dole Lanka and Vita Organi for banana cultivation in Chandrika Wewa Division of Walawa Region, separately; and
(iii) whether he admits the fact that the said lands were not provided following the proper methodology ;
() ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Susil Ranasinghe - Deputy Minister of Land and Irrigation) , , , .
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Education, Higher Education and Vocational Education:
(i) the number of Teachers Colleges available in Sri Lanka;
(ii) whether steps will be taken to convert those colleges into other training centres related to the field of education since the number of students learning at the Teachers Ccolleges is very low;

(iii) whether steps will be taken to conduct a one-year, full-time postgraduate diploma course at the Teachers Colleges referred to above since the National Institute of Education is an institution qualified for awarding degrees; and
(iv) if not, the action that will be taken in the future regarding the Teachers Colleges concerned?

GRANT OF STATE LAND IN MAHIYANGANAYA TOWN TO
MR. Y. M. RATHNAPALA ON LEASE: DETAILS
asked the Minister of Agriculture, Livestock, Land and Irrigation:

(a) Is he aware that - (i) the foundation stone was laid in the year 2004 in the land adjacent to the Bank of Ceylon in Mahiyanganaya Town for construction of an agricultural sales centre; (ii) the incumbent President, as the then Minister of Agriculture, took preliminary measures to take over the above-mentioned land to the Department of Agrarian Services; (iii) requests had been made for it by the Mahiyanganaya Agrarian Services Committee and farmers; (iv) approval has been given under letter No.

4/10/75144 of the Land Commissioner General to grant the above-mentioned land on preferential lease basis to Mr. Y.M. Rathnapala, who is residing at 48th Post, Arawatta, Mahiyanganaya; and (v) State lands are granted on preferential basis only on compelling and special grounds? (b) Will he state - (i) the reason for selecting a person who is over 80 years of age to transfer the above-mentioned land; (ii) whether he is aware that, when alienating State lands, the availability of sufficient lands for Government needs and the physical fitness of the selected recipient is taken into consideration, and that State lands are not usually given to a person over 60 years of age; (iii) whether the above-mentioned considerations were taken into account when granting the said land; and (iv) whether approval for the lease referred to above will be revoked? (c) If not, why?
: TAKEOVER OF COMMUNITY WATER SUPPLY CENTRES BY
NATIONAL WATER SUPPLY AND DRAINAGE BOARD:
asked the Minister of Urban Development, Construction and Housing:
(i) whether the Community Water Supply Centres functioning under the Department of National Community Water Supply are to be taken over to the National Water Supply and Drainage Board;
(iii) whether all the properties belonging to the said Community Water Supply Centres will be taken over by the National Water Supply and Drainage Board;
(iv) whether he is aware that the Community Water Supply Unit in New Medagame,
Dehiattakandiya has been taken over by the Board without conducting a formal audit; and
(v) whether approval of Cabinet of Ministers has been obtained for the said takeover?

: SAND PIERS AND DEMAND FOR SAND: DETAILS

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) separately, the number of sand piers located along the major rivers, tributaries, creeks and canals and the number of people engaged in occupations related to them;
(ii) the number of those that are operated legally, out of the number of piers referred to above;
(iii) whether he is aware that there are illegal sand piers as well;
(iv) if so, the legal action that will be taken against such illegal sand piers; and
(v) the measures to be taken regarding the environmental harm caused by sand mining?
(b) Will he also inform this House -
(i) whether the annual demand of sand for construction activities in Sri Lanka has been estimated; (ii) whether it is possible to meet that demand;
(iii) if not, whether alternative ways are available to meet the demand;
(iv) the new sources of sand available in the country;
(v) whether priority will be given to the new sources of sand referred to above; and (vi) if not, the reasons for it?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Anton Jayakody - Deputy Minister of Environment) , .
() , ? asked the Minister of Urban Development, Construction and Housing:
(i) whether the Urban Development Authority has prepared a plan to develop the Town of Deiyandara;
(ii) the number of proposals that have been implemented by now, out of those contained in the plan referred to above;
(iii) the measures that will be taken in the future to implement the remaining proposals;

(iv) whether it has been proposed to remove the Deiyandara Primary School from its current location according to the above-mentioned plan; and (v) the institution/individual authorized to implement the proposal referred to above?
: CONTROL OF STRAY DOG POPULATION: MEASURES
() , ? asked the Minister of Health and Mass Media:
(i) the measures that were taken in the year 2025 to control the stray dog population;

(ii) whether steps will be taken to prevent dogs and puppies raised in households from being brought and abandoned on roads and public places; and (iii) the measures that will be taken to minimize dog bites and road accidents caused by the increase in the stray dog population?
() ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Hansaka Wijemuni - Deputy Minister of Health and Mass Media) , .
() , ? asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Education, Higher Education and Vocational Education:

(a) Will she inform this House - (i) the total number of students studying at all the faculties of the University of Colombo at present; (ii) the number of those who have been provided with hostel facilities, out of the students referred to above; (iii) whether she accepts that a considerable number of students do not get hostel facilities accordingly; and (iv) the number of hostels possessed by the University of Colombo, their names and the number of those as per the categorization of female, male and mixed hostels, separately? (b) Will she also inform this House -

(i) whether she is aware that the land in Colombo 02, where the Muttiah Girls' Hostel, which provided hostel facilities to around 800 female students of the University of Colombo, had been located was taken over in the year 2020;

(ii) the name of the entity which currently has possession of the land, where the aforesaid hostel was located; (iii) whether she is aware that no development work has been carried out there although more than five years has lapsed after the demolition of the said hostel; and (iv) if so, whether the entire land or a portion thereof will be returned to the University of Colombo? (c) If not, why? () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Harini Amarasuriya) , .

"Indian salt shipment arrives A shipment of salt imported from India was set to arrive in Sri Lanka yesterday (21) night, as part of efforts to address the current salt shortage in the country, the Minister of Trade, Commerce and Food Security Wasantha Samarasinghe said.

Samarasinghe confirmed that the consignment includes a total of 3,050 metric tonnes (MT) of salt. Of this, 250 MT have been imported by the private sector, while the remaining 2,800 MT were brought in by the State-run National Salt Company."

So, it is important, Hon. Deputy Speaker, that this shortage of salt is solved in the proper way. I feel that when a particular person in the private sector controls one sector, there is a conflict of interest. Therefore, we must make sure that there is proper regulation in place; there has to be a regulatory authority looking into it. In the past, we had price control on all items. We have moved away from that concept. But, the Governments fair trading principles must be properly monitored. So, that is why we have government institutions set up to look into it. But, unfortunately, with all that and having warned from last December onwards about an impending shortage of salt in the country, the Government was very slow in taking action and finally resulted in the salt mafia controlling the price of salt in the market. And, who is behind this salt mafia? Is the Trade Ministry aware of that? Are the Trade Ministrys officials knowingly assisting this mafia?

Particularly, when I see this news item, it is quite apparent that from Bombay a salt shipment had started and has arrived here already. But, it is only a small fraction that the private sector can import. A large fraction is imported by the State sector. We know that the State Trading (General) Corporation is used as a ploy, as a cover to cover up corruption. It had been done by past administrations also, in which we were also part of and we had been speaking up in the Cabinet. The relevant Ministers have to be careful. In Ministries like the Ministry of Trade and the Ministry of Finance, there are bureaucrats who are corrupt. That is another problem. Getting rid of corruption is not only on politicians. What about bureaucrats? Bureaucrats are also to be blamed; they, too, are involved in this type of action, which finally results in the poor general public having to suffer, paying a heavy price for a very simple item like salt.
Sir, I would also like to mention this.

Hon. Presiding Member, emphasizing the importance of this piece of legislation we are discussing today, I would like to say that the delivery of promises we gave to the people is important. One of them is to facilitate business, to make it easier to do business in Sri Lanka. Saying no to corruption and having necessary systems and processes in place, Sri Lanka would once again be recognized as a nation serious about addressing its chronic issues. One of them relates to making use of online facilities by the certification agencies.

But, before getting on to technical details, I would like to highlight a point made by an Hon. Member a short while ago, referring to conflicts of interest. It is important to recognize the requirement to disclose the conflicts of interest. But, Madam, apart from disclosure, it is more important to ensure your ethical conduct while you are on respective boards or government institutions. What was lacking in the past was mentioning their affiliations. But, when decisions were made, they were actively involved in those processes. They were passing information to outsiders who had business interest. We do not have to go far. At the Committee of Parliament inquiring into the Central Bank Bond scam, several Members seated there, while discussions were going on those sensitive matters, made phone calls and shared information with outsiders. Today, those very Members are trying to preach us about conflicts of interest. So, there is absolutely no substance in what those fake Members say with their understanding of conflicts of interest. They are trying to preach us about conflicts of interest, whereas they had breached the very essence or the fundamentals of it while taking part in those Parliamentary Committees. So, for the members of the public, it is important to recognize that; even though they are trying to portray a different conduct, their reputation in terms of doing wrong things is well known to the society.

As a nation, we need to rely on the members of the business community. There are several capable individuals in the business community who have contributed to the success of several businesses. As the Government, we are serious about getting the their input where necessary, considering their conduct, the past track record and particularly, their not engaging in wrong activities and corruption-related transactions. Then, we

would also like to get business enterprises involved. From the discussions that the Government is having to take Sri Lanka forward to a better place, we cannot leave the business community out and go in a separate direction. No, we will work with the business community, get ideas from those individuals, experts of the business community out there, to take Sri Lanka to a better place. Therefore, we will work with the private sector business community to build this nation, which was ruined by those politicians and the corrupt culture they had built.
Madam, coming back to the subject matter, I would say that it is important to recognize the validity and efficiency these systems would bring about in the nation.

Madam, on the one hand, with these process improvements we are referring to, we could say no to corruption and minimize the opportunities and chances for corruption and on the other, would track and trace sources of revenue generation, which is a very important step as far as the country is concerned and the situation we are in, as of now.

Facilitation of businesses to continue their activities is very important. I will take one example to demonstrate that. We have not limited it only to talking, Madam, but have implemented some of these digitization initiatives. The agency related to todays Debate is the Comptroller General's Office. We have implemented a digitization process there, which requires no individual to go to the Comptroller General's Office to give an application. We implemented it early this year, in January or February, and upon inquiry into the success of the digitization process, the Chambers indicated to me that even though we have implemented digitization, people still have to walk into those counters. Early this week, I, in fact, went to the Comptroller General's Office to see whether it is true, whether people still have to come to the counters. There are five counters available at the office. Only one counter was operating and a few people were there at the counter. I went and spoke to a person at the counter, who was from the business community and had come to ge the support of the officers. I asked him, "Why did you have to come here today, when there are online services available?" Madam, he mentioned that he wanted to follow up on an application he had made. I, in fact, thought that the application had been pending for a long

time. I went there on a Monday morning. Then, I asked him, "When did you apply?" He said that he applied it on Friday and had come on Monday morning to check on its progress, which, in a way, is a good thing to have an efficient service delivered, even though there was no necessity with hardly a single working day passing from Friday to Monday. Then, I asked him, "Why did you come today? You made the application on Friday and you are here on Monday asking the officials about its progress." We never know why people come there; people may still be used to previous practices, which are not good practices, unfortunately. Then, that person explained the reason why he came. It was due to an emergency; they had ordered some spare parts related to aircraft engines, which they needed to get cleared urgently. That is why he had come in person. Then, I asked from the Department also, "Is there not a process to facilitate this type of outliers or exceptional situations, emergencies? So, they also explained to the person who had come there. That example is just to highlight what we have implemented so far. Within this six-month period, we hav been going ahead with the digital journey in this country. The business community is benefiting, as we speak, from this engagement. Otherwise, every day, they have to send people to those institutions, which is a cost to them and leads to bribery and corruption as well. That is one example. There are many other examples I can give, but for the time being, I will limit it to the Sri Lanka Standards Institution. There, out of seven processes, two with the highest number of traffic are already done online or digitally delivered. These are examples to show the deliveries of the present Government, what we have implemented facilitating and saving cost to the business community and making it easier to do business in Sri Lanka.

, , there is a new culture we are inculcating. People have voted in favour of that culture. It is an evolution from the manual-based transactions mentioned in the Gazette we are debating today. We are evolving into the digital space, but what is more important is that the Government is on a mission or a journey to deliver what we had promised to people who trusted this Government without knowing who we are.

What they trusted in is the expertise our Members had, the ingenuity in our approach and the governance approach we will implement in Sri Lanka. That is what we are implementing as the days pass by. Support is extended to large businesses, corporations operating here and to the SME sector as well. Our intention is to provide that support and help achieve the aspirations of the

businesses. Similarly, it is also our intention to ensure that the aspirations of the people, particularly of the parents, are achieved and delivered. Parents are worried that their children would not have a country to live in after they complete their education. This Government is delivering on those promises.

That is why it is important to discuss these important policies in this House. Madam, today, I was expecting that we would get some suggestions to amend the Regulations we have presented today. There have been discussions, but however, unfortunately, there were no valuable suggestions or recommendations made relating to the matter we are deliberating today. Some Hon. Members were discussing about salt. Madam, I cannot amend this legislation with salt; I need input relating to the Regulations under this legislation. They were saying that we are implementing the law without attending to previous corruptions. Recommendations are required for the Regulations brought under this piece of legislation we are deliberating today.

So, let us not make the excuse that resources are a constraint for us to deliver. Let us get it done together with your suggestions. You are able to contribute to these valued debates and discussions.

Similarly, the Government is also engaged in business through our State-owned enterprises. It is important for us to ensure that the governance framework of those businesses is improved. We have an accountable mechanism, that if the entities are not able to deliver the results, the people of the country have to finance those activities as well. Therefore, separate initiatives are underway, as we are discussing, to improve those arrangements, to revise those legislations and to implement them in a timely manner.

Similarly, when we bring in new legislations, it is not only the aspect of the Government that we consider, but we also have dialogues and discussions with the industry as well. Just to highlight an example, we wanted to repeal the SVAT given to businesses. It is also known that the Government has laid the road map even with dates being identified. The SVAT will be repealed with a suitable mechanism implemented, under which entities would be able to submit their documentation through an online platform, the Inland Revenue Department would be able to go through them and provide the applicable refund within the shortest possible time. In this discussion, we engaged with the industries, particularly with the garment segment, which is considered the most-affected. We have had multiple discussions with the industry so far to accommodate their suggestions. As of now, they have suggested to consider trading houses also in this equation. That shows the cooperation between the business community and the present Government. We are not making high-handed decisions; we are making decisions for the betterment of the country. It is Sri Lanka - the North, the South, the East and the West - that we are going to build together with the input and the support of the business community. Another example to demonstrate our engagement with the industry is the continuous discussions the the ceramic manufacturers had with the Government to explain the challenges they are going through.
I am extremely happy to announce to this House, Madam, that the National Tariff Policy the Hon. President mentioned in his Budget Speech is also going to be established.

This week, we are going to establish the National Tariff Policy Committee. Its inaugural session will be held this week. We invite the industries to coordinate with the channels that are available through the Ministry of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development, to take part in those discussions and to submit their suggestions, proposals and challenges they have. So, we have a mechanism in place in the country. For the first time in the history of Sri Lanka, instead of politicians deciding on what should be the tax, a mechanism is now put in place to decided what should be the Excise Duty on articles imported into the country. So, that is a victory and a milestone we have achieved as a country, but we need to make sure that we improve it continuously. It is not only about establishing a committee and having its first meeting, but continuation of the activities. Therefore, I invite the business community to engaged with the process. The Ministry of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development has played a tremendous role in getting this done.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Deputy Minister, your time is up.

() ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Harshana Suriyapperuma) The officials of the Ministry of Finance also have contributed to the success of these initiatives. So, as a nation, we should be able to move forward and achieve
many things that we could not achieve earlier as a country. We are are on a mission, Madam, and are hopeful that, as a country, we would achieve it together.
Thank you very much. . . Question put, and agreed to.
EMPOWERMENT OF SMALL AND MEDIUM SCALE
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) , the Hon. (Dr.) S. Sri Bavanandarajah. Hon. Member, you have three minutes.
() . ( () . ) (The Hon. (Dr.) S. Sri Bavanandarajah) Hon. Presiding Member, I second the Adjournment Motion moved by the Hon. Rajeevan Jeyachandramoorthy.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) The Hon. M. Nizam Kariapper. You have seven minutes.
. ( . ) (The Hon. M. Nizam Kariapper, PC) Hon. Presiding Member, when you spoke in Tamil, I think everybody was shocked.

Thank you, Madam, for the opportunity to speak on this Adjournment Motion aimed at empowering small and medium exporters in the Northern Province. I rise today to support this Motion, but, of course, with a vital amendment; the scope of this discussion should be extended to include the Eastern Province as well is my proposal. The economic and social realities of the Northern and the Eastern Provinces are deeply intertwined, their challenges are similar and so is their untapped potential. Both provinces are rich in culture, traditions and natural resources. But, decades of conflict, displacement and economic neglect have left them lagging behind. Today, if we are to speak seriously about inclusive national growth, we must focus on empowering small and medium enterprises in these regions, enabling them to become prospective exporters.

Madam, I wish to draw your attention to another important and critical matter that has gone unnoticed. Under the Ninth Schedule of the Constitution - Provincial Council List - matters relating to promotion of agriculture, fisheries, co-operative industries, cottage industries and local economic development fall within the jurisdiction of the Provincial Council. This clearly reflects the framers intent that economic development of each province is not a central subject alone, but one that must be driven from the ground up with the Provincial Council paying a lead role. Ignoring this structure is not only a policy failure, but also a constitutional abdication.

The Northern and Eastern Provinces have distinct sectors with export potential, which could contribute meaningfully to the national economy. Let us start one by one. Culinary heritage and agro exports, traditional food items - you know about Jaffna traditional food items - organic products and preserved seafood from these regions are of high demand, especially among the overseas community. With proper training, packaging and marketing support, these items could be developed into powerful export brands. I will take an interesting example. When I visit Jaffna Courts, I go to "Rasavin Wanam". Just in front of it, there is a small boutique, which has a sweet item called "elluppahu" , a blackball full of nutritional value. You do not get that in any part of the country. So, these have to be promoted. I always go there and have that snack.
Then, handloom and traditional textiles. Our handloom sector is a cultural treasure. It also presents a strong case for premium exports in the global sustainable
fashion and ethical trading market if only be invested in modernization, design, innovation and e-commerce integrations.

Then, Palmyra-based products. Palmyra is abandoned in both provinces and holds immense value from jaggery, vinegar to fibre products and handicrafts. But, this industry remains informal and fragmented. It needs organized support, quality certification and research-led value addition.

Also, you get seafood and marine products. Our coastal belt, particularly in the North and the East, are rich with exportable seafood like crab, cuttlefish and dried fish. But, we lack a cold chain, export licence and post-harvest processing support necessary to compete internationally.

While the initiative of the Central Government and private sector participation are vital, there is a missing partner in the conversation - the provincial council. For far too long now, the Northern and the Eastern Provincial Councils have not been functioning. Without electoral representation, the local mandate and the institutional capacity to plan and deliver, we are limiting the potential for a truly localized responsive development. Therefore, Madam, I call upon this House and the Government to immediately take steps to hold the Provincial Councils Elections. It is essential that the provincial councils become an active partner in economic development of these regions as they are best placed to understand the local needs, to mobilize rural entrepreneurs and coordinate support across the departments.

Therefore, Madam, I urge the Government to expand the focus of export development programmes to both the Northern and the Eastern Provinces, establish SME export incubation zones in key districts like Jaffna,Vavuniya, Batticaloa and Ampara, support handloom clustsers, palmyrah co-operatives, seafood collectives and provide modern tools, marketing training and credit access, facilitate diaspora engagement and overseas promotion through targeted trade fair and digital campaign and finally, to resort to full democratic governance in the provinces by holding the long overdue Provincial Councils Elections. Only then, can we build partnership with the Centre, the provinces and the people, a triangular that is essential for genuine and lasting development.

Madam, in conclusion, I would say let us not look at the North and the East merely as regions recovering, but as engines of growth. Let us also believe in the capacity of our people, their skills, their resilience and their dreams. Let us provide them the institutions, infrastructure and inspiration they need to connect to the world as confident sub-exporters.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Mayilvaganam Jegatheeswaran. You have three minutes.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) The Hon. (Dr.) Ramanathan Archchuna. You have seven minutes.

Thank you, Hon. Rajeevan Jeyachandramoorthy, for bringing this Adjournment Motion.

It being 5.30 p.m., THE HON. PRESIDING MEMBER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly until 9.30 a.m. on Friday, 23rd May, 2025.
